factoid: Borís asked Rostóv where he was off to.
Rostóv said he was carrying a message to His Majesty.
Borís said 'There he is!' pointing to the Grand Duke.
Borís thought Rostóv had addressed the Grand Duke as 'His Highness'.
The Grand Duke stood a hundred paces away from them, wearing a helmet and a Horse Guards jacket, and shouted something to a pale white uniformed Austrian officer.
Rostóv said that the person he saw was the Grand Duke.
Rostóv said he wanted the commander in chief or the Emperor.
Rostóv was about to spur his horse.
Count Berg shouted 'Count! Count!'.
Count Berg ran up from the other side, eager as Borís.
Count Berg said he was wounded in his right hand.
Count Berg showed his bleeding right hand with a handkerchief tied around it.
Count Berg said he remained at the front.
Count Berg held his sword in his left hand.
Count Berg said his family, the von Bergs, have been knights.
Count Berg said something more.
Rostóv did not wait to hear Count Berg and rode away.
Rostóv passed the Guards and traversed an empty space.
Rostóv avoided getting in front of the first line again, as he had done when the Horse Guards charged.
Rostóv followed the line of reserves.
Rostóv went far around the place where the hottest musket fire and cannonade were heard.
Rostóv suddenly heard musket fire close in front of him and behind Rostóv's troops.
Rostóv could never have expected the enemy to be behind Rostóv's troops.
Rostóv thought 'What can it be?'.
Rostóv thought 'The enemy in the rear of our army? Impossible!'.
Rostóv was seized by panic of fear for himself and for the outcome of the whole battle.
Rostóv reflected 'But be that what it may.'.
Rostóv reflected 'There is no riding round it now.'.
Rostóv reflected 'I must look for the commander in chief here.'.
Rostóv reflected 'If all is lost it is for me to perish with the rest.'.
Rostóv felt foreboding of evil.
The foreboding increased as Rostóv rode into the region behind the village of Pratzen.
The region behind the village of Pratzen was full of troops of all kinds.
Rostóv kept asking 'What does it mean? What is it? Whom are they firing at? Who is firing?'.
Rostóv approached Russian and Austrian soldiers running in confused crowds across his path.
A crowd of fugitives told Rostóv in Russian, German, and Czech: 'The devil knows! They've killed everybody! It's all up now!'.
The crowd of fugitives understood what was happening as little as Rostóv.
One person shouted 'Kill the Germans!'.
Someone shouted 'May the devil take them—the traitors!'.
A German muttered 'Zum Henker diese Russen!'.
A German shouted 'Hang these Russians!'.
Several wounded men passed along the road.
Words of abuse, screams, and groans mingled in a general hubbub.
The firing died down.
Rostóv learned later that Russian and Austrian soldiers had been firing at one another.
Rostóv thought 'My God! What does it all mean?'.
Rostóv thought 'And here, where at any moment the Emperor may see them... But no, these must be only a handful of scoundrels.'.
Rostóv thought 'It will soon be over.'.
Rostóv thought 'It can't be that, it can't be!'.
Rostóv thought 'Only to get past them quicker, quicker!'.
Rostóv could not think of defeat and flight.
Rostóv saw French cannon and French troops on the Pratzen Heights.
Rostóv had been ordered to look for the commander in chief there.
Rostóv could not, did not wish to, believe that.
Rostóv had been ordered to look for Kutúzov and the Emperor near the village of Pratzen.
Neither Kutúzov nor the Emperor were there.
Only disorganized crowds of troops of various kinds were there.
Rostóv urged his already weary horse to get quickly past these crowds.
The crowds became more disorganized the farther Rostóv went.
The highroad Rostóv came out on was thronged with calèches, carriages of all sorts, and Russian and Austrian soldiers of all arms.
Some soldiers were wounded and some were not.
The whole mass droned and jostled in confusion.
Cannon balls were flying from the French batteries stationed on the Pratzen Heights.
Rostóv kept asking 'Where is the Emperor? Where is Kutúzov?'.
Rostóv got no answer from anyone.
Rostóv seized a soldier by his collar.
Rostóv forced the soldier to answer.
The soldier said 'Eh, brother! They've all bolted long ago!'.
The soldier laughed for some reason.
The soldier shook himself free.
